thread.title: Aust. sharemarket rallies 1.8%
thread.title_full: Aust. sharemarket rallies 1.8% | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Michael Roddan
title: Aust. sharemarket rallies 1.8%
text:
THE Australian share market has started a fresh quarter on the front foot, rising more than 1.5 per cent higher to close well above the 5000-point level.
The local market was in sharp recovery mode after logging its worst quarterly performance in four years during the three months to September, but upbeat global leads and better-than-expected official manufacturing data in China buoyed Australian equities on Thursday.
At the 4.15pm official market close, the benchmark ASX 200 index was up 90.5 points, or 1.8 per cent, to 5112.1, while the broader All Ordinaries added 85.5 points, or 1.7 per cent, to 5144.1.
Australian equities were following in the steps of European and US markets, which largely echoed the 2 per cent bounce across the Asian region yesterday.
Fresh economic data from China buoyed sentiment, with the official manufacturing purchasing managers’ index printing at 49.8 for September, ahead of expectations of 49.7.
Meanwhile, a private sector index from Caixin, which was released 45 minutes later, also slightly beat expectations, but remained at a six-and-a-half year low and showed the quickest deterioration in operating conditions faced by Chinese manufacturers since March 2009.
China’s manufacturing data had in late August sparked a fresh bout of panic selling on the Chinese equity markets which then infected global bourses on Black Monday, leading the MSCI world index, which tracks global share markets, on an 11 per cent rout through to the end of September.
But the latest data breathed confidence into the market, which was mirrored across Asia with Japan’s Nikkei index up more than 2 per cent and Hong Kong’s Hang Seng more than 1 per cent stronger.
The figures spurred a rally in the Australian dollar, which was pushed to its highest point in more than a week, jumping above the US70.5c level.
Investor sentiment was also buoyed by strong Australian manufacturing and job vacancy figures.
The Australian Industry Group’s performance of manufacturing index for September showed the nation’s manufacturing sector expanded for a third straight month to its strongest point since May, while the Australian Bureau of Statistics’ job vacancy figures showed openings at their highest level for nearly three years.
The energy sector was the star of the local market, despite a dip in global oil prices overnight on Wednesday, with the sector charging forward on news that the world’s biggest consumer of oil may not be slowing as much as feared.
Oil Search added 2.09 per cent to $7.32, while Woodside Petroleum gained 2.87 per cent to $29.76.
Meanwhile, the mining sector was not shaken by the sixth consecutive fall in iron ore prices overnight. Copper miner OZ Minerals led the sector higher after a private equity firm scooped up a 10 per cent stake in the company, labelling it “undervalued”.
Oz Minerals surged 19.3 per cent to $3.95
BHP Billiton grew 2.07 per cent to $22.68, while Rio Tinto put on 2.02 per cent to $49.58.
Financial stocks were also strong, with ANZ announcing chief executive Mike Smith will be replaced by Shayne Elliott.
Commonwealth Bank rallied 2.13 per cent to $74.27, while ANZ shares improved 1.62 per cent to $27.52.
National Australia Bank lifted 1.87 per cent to $30.54 while Westpac gained 2.32 per cent to $30.39.
Consumer staples swung into the black after earlier weakness.
Wesfarmers added 1.68 per cent to $39.88, while Woolworths gained 2.66 per cent to $25.50.
Meanwhile, Qantas rose 2.69 per cent to $3.82, while Telstra added 1.78 per cent to $5.71.
Looking ahead, the ABS releases retail trade figures for August on Friday.
 Australian share market rallies 1.8%
